dt: {bc}to free from what is harsh or disagreeable {bc}{sx|polish||}
{bc}to minimize (something, such as a fault) especially in order to allay anger or ill will

dt.t: his main job is to {wi}smooth{/wi} over the friction that so often arises
conciliation {wi}smoothed{/wi} the way to an agreement
{wi}smoothed{/wi} down the folds of her dress

dt: {bc}to cause to lie evenly and in order {bc}{sx|preen||}
{bc}to free (a graph, a collection of data, etc.) from irregularities

shortdef: to free from what is harsh or disagreeable : polish

dt: {bc}to make (problems, difficulties, etc.) less serious {bc}to remove (problems, difficulties, etc.)

dt.t: We'll help {it}smooth away{/it} any legal trouble.

shortdef: to make (problems, difficulties, etc.) less serious : to remove (problems, difficulties, etc.)

dt.t: After we dug up the soil, we {it}smoothed{/it} it {it}out{/it} before we planted the seeds.

dt: {bc}to make (something) easier by removing or dealing with problems

dt.t: We will {it}smooth out{/it} the election process by next year.
She tried to {phrase}smooth things out{/phrase} with her daughter-in-law, but the damage was done.

shortdef: to make (something) easier by removing or dealing with problems

dt: {bc}to make (a disagreement, problem, difficulty, etc.) seem less serious than it really is

dt.t: Don't worry about missing the application deadline—we'll {it}smooth{/it} that {it}over{/it} with the office.
She {it}smoothed over{/it} the objections to his candidacy.

shortdef: to make (a disagreement, problem, difficulty, etc.) seem less serious than it really is
